content: Chest Pain Evaluation: MUST rule out life-threatening causes first: ACS (troponin, ECG), aortic dissection (BP differential, CT angio), PE (d-dimer, CTPA), pneumothorax (CXR), cardiac tamponade (echo). RED FLAGS: crushing substernal pain, radiation to arm/jaw, diaphoresis, dyspnea, hypotension, syncope. Cardiac: exertional pain relieved by rest/nitrates suggests angina; prolonged pain >20min suggests MI; positional pain suggests pericarditis. Pulmonary: pleuritic pain worse with breathing (PE, pneumonia, pleuritis). GI: burning epigastric pain (GERD), worse with meals. MSK: reproducible with palpation. Risk stratification: HEART score, TIMI score. Workup: troponin x2-3, ECG, CXR minimum. Disposition based on risk and clinical suspicion.
name: Chest Pain - Diagnostic Approach
